unnormalised: Okay, so someone asked about the best way to write LaTeX equations for their math homework. Bhai, let me tell you, it's a journey. Forget everything you think you know about typing; suddenly, `a + b = c` becomes `a + b = c`. Groundbreaking, I know! But hold on, it gets weirder.
normalised: Okay, so someone asked about the best way to write L-A-T-e-X equations for their math homework. Bhai, let me tell you, it's a journey. Forget everything you think you know about typing; suddenly, a plus b equals c becomes a plus b equals c. Groundbreaking, I know! But hold on, it gets weirder.

unnormalised: Want a fraction? Easy, right? Wrong! It's `\frac{numerator}{denominator}`. I swear, the first time I saw that, I thought I'd accidentally opened a portal to another dimension. And don't even get me started on integrals. They look so elegant on paper, but typing `\int_{lower}^{upper} f(x) dx` feels like summoning a mathematical demon. My advice? Copy-paste is your best friend.
normalised: Want a fraction? Easy, right? Wrong! It's backslash frac numerator denominator. I swear, the first time I saw that, I thought I'd accidentally opened a portal to another dimension. And don't even get me started on integrals. They look so elegant on paper, but typing backslash integral from lower to upper of f of x d x feels like summoning a mathematical demon. My advice? Copy-paste is your best friend.

unnormalised: Seriously though, LaTeX is powerful. Once you get the hang of it, you can write beautiful equations that would make Ramanujan proud (or at least slightly impressed). Just remember to breathe, double-check your curly braces (they're the bane of my existence), and don't be afraid to Google "LaTeX symbol for...". Stack Exchange is your guru.
normalised: Seriously though, L-A-T-e-X is powerful. Once you get the hang of it, you can write beautiful equations that would make Ramanujan proud (or at least slightly impressed). Just remember to breathe, double-check your curly braces (they're the bane of my existence), and don't be afraid to Google "L-A-T-e-X symbol for...". Stack Exchange is your guru.

unnormalised: And a pro-tip? Use a LaTeX editor with live preview. Seeing your code transform into glorious mathematical symbols in real-time is strangely satisfying. It's like magic, but with more backslashes and fewer rabbits. Good luck with your homework! Youâ€™ll need it. Especially if you have to write something as crazy as `E=mc^2`.
normalised: And a pro-tip? Use a L-A-T-e-X editor with live preview. Seeing your code transform into glorious mathematical symbols in real-time is strangely satisfying. It's like magic, but with more backslashes and fewer rabbits. Good luck with your homework! You'll need it. Especially if you have to write something as crazy as E equals m c squared.
